docs.snippet: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 9. -- The Chilean railroad strike has given President Arturo Alessandri an opportunity to clean up a political situation that had been annoying him for more than two years. Santiago dispatches today announce the railroad and other...
docs.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 9. -- The Chilean railroad strike has given President Arturo Alessandri an opportunity to clean up a political situation that had been annoying him for more than two years. Santiago dispatches today announce the railroad and other strikes have been settled and that the situation is again normal.
docs.abstract: Pres Alessandri prorogues Cong, decrees state of siege, ends strikes and arrests 600 foes

headline.main: CHILE'S PRESIDENT ARRESTS 600 FOES; Prorogues Congress, Decrees a State of Siege, Ends Strikes and Seizes Politicians. HE CHARGES A RED PLOT Santiago Reports Situation Is Normal -- Two Newspaper Owners Among Those Held. CHILE'S PRESIDENT ARRESTS 600 FOES

docs.snippet: MOSCOW, Feb. 10. -- Nikolai Bukharin, chief of the editorial board of Izvestia, the principal government newspaper, and one of the foremost if not the foremost of Soviet publicists, has fallen into disfavor with the leadership of the Communist party.
docs.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Feb. 10. -- Nikolai Bukharin, chief of the editorial board of Izvestia, the principal government newspaper, and one of the foremost if not the foremost of Soviet publicists, has fallen into disfavor with the leadership of the Communist party.
docs.abstract: Told by newspaper Pravda to correct allegedly libelous statement on Russian people made in Izvestia ed

headline.main: HIGH SOVIET EDITOR AGAIN IN DISFAVOR; Communist Newspaper Says Bukharin of Official Organ Libels Russians. REACTIONARY TREND SEEN Izvestia Writer Rose to High Post After Recanting Attacks on Stalin's Policies. HIGH SOVIET EDITOR AGAIN IN DISFAVOR

byline.original: By HAROLD DENNY.Special Cable to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 12. -- South American governments are attributing communistic character to opposition movements which have no connection with communism, according to an editorial in today's Prensa.
docs.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 12. -- South American governments are attributing communistic character to opposition movements which have no connection with communism, according to an editorial in today's Prensa.
docs.abstract: Buenos Aires Prensa denies Red menace; says South Amer govts are classing all foes as Communists

headline.main: BUENOS AIRES PAPER DENIES RED MENACE; Prensa Says South American Governments Are Classing All Foes as Communists.

docs.snippet: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 14. -- The Chaco peace conference recessed for an indefinite period today after appointing an executive committee to consider any matters that might come up during the recess. The conference can be called together again by its...
docs.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 14. -- The Chaco peace conference recessed for an indefinite period today after appointing an executive committee to consider any matters that might come up during the recess. The conference can be called together again by its president, Foreign Minister Carlos Saavedra Lamas of Argentina, whenever he thinks it desirable or upon the request of any delegation.

headline.main: CHACO CONFERENCE VOTES LONG RECESS; Unlikely to Reconvene Until Bolivia and Paraguay Induct New Administrations.

byline.original: Special Cable to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: The Architectural League of New York will celebrate its fiftieth anniversary Tuesday with the opening to the public of its annual exhibition at the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street.
docs.lead_paragraph: The Architectural League of New York will celebrate its fiftieth anniversary Tuesday with the opening to the public of its annual exhibition at the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street.

headline.main: ARCHITECTS' SHOW TO OPEN TUESDAY; League to Celebrate Its 50th Anniversary With Exhibit of Several Types of Art.

docs.snippet: Foreign exchange rates declined in erratic trading last week. In marked contrast to the previous weakness of the dollar, which saw the exporting of gold for the first time since the Fall of 1934, midweek developments sent the dollar up to a high of...
docs.lead_paragraph: Foreign exchange rates declined in erratic trading last week. In marked contrast to the previous weakness of the dollar, which saw the exporting of gold for the first time since the Fall of 1934, midweek developments sent the dollar up to a high of 99.82 cents on Thursday, and it closed at 99.24 cents to register a gain of .16 cent for the week.

headline.main: FOREIGN EXCHANGE RATES; WEEK ENDED FEB. 15, 1936.
